original_title: Sri Lanka rupee closes stronger at 314.50/315.00 to the US dollar
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT -Sri Lanka rupee was closed at 314.50/315.00 rupees to the US dollar Wednesday, stronger from 318/320 on Monday dealers said.
Sri Lanka’s central bank is operating broadly deflationary open market operations supportive of a stronger rupee, but has an ad hoc exchange rate policy.

The ad hoc policy involves flipping regime from a peg to buy dollars (strong side convertibility) and suddenly staying away and avoid providing weak side convertibility, effectively flipping the regime to a float.
The collapsing currency was reigned in by moral suasion twice so far this year.

However if monetary policy is inflationary (money is printed to cut rates claiming inflation is low after credit picks up as had happened in previous credit cycles in 2011, 2015, 2018 and 2020) the rupee will tend to depreciate and moral suasion will be ineffective.
A bond maturing on 15.05.2030 closed at 13.60/60 percent down from Monday’s close at 13.80/14.00 percent.
A bond maturing on 01.05.2028 closed at 13.50/70 percent from closing at 13.95/14.10 percent.
A bond maturing on 15.09.2027 closed at 14.25/30 percent steady from closing at 14.45/65 percent.
A bond maturing on 15.05.2026 closed at 14.50/65 percent down from closing at 14.75/85 percent.
A bond maturing on 01.07.2025 closed at 15.10/20 percent down from closing at 15.20/50 percent. (Colombo/Aug02/2023)
